title: Quiz 12: Health Promotion
description: NCK 2025 Predictions for Health Promotion (Set 5). Contains 50 questions.

questions.question: What is the primary goal of health promotion?

options.text: To prevent disease and improve quality of life

questions.explanation: Health promotion focuses on preventing disease, enhancing health, and improving quality of life through education, lifestyle changes, and supportive environments rather than treating illness.

questions.question: Which model emphasizes the importance of individual beliefs in health behavior change?
questions.explanation: The Health Belief Model centers on individual perceptions of susceptibility, severity, benefits, and barriers to adopting health behaviors.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a primary prevention strategy?
questions.explanation: Immunization prevents the onset of disease, which is the essence of primary prevention, whereas screening and rehabilitation are secondary and tertiary prevention, respectively.

questions.question: Which is the most effective way to promote behavior change in a community?
questions.explanation: Community participation in planning ensures programs are culturally relevant and sustainable, leading to better behavior change outcomes.

questions.question: What does the “social determinants of health” refer to?

options.text: Economic and social conditions influencing health

questions.explanation: Social determinants include socioeconomic status, education, environment, and social support affecting health outcomes beyond genetics or individual behaviors.

questions.question: Which health promotion strategy focuses on creating supportive environments?
questions.explanation: Creating supportive environments often requires policy changes and advocacy to enable healthy choices, such as smoke-free zones or access to parks.

questions.question: What is the best method to evaluate the success of a health promotion program?

options.text: Assessing behavioral changes and health outcomes

questions.explanation: Evaluation should focus on actual changes in behavior and health indicators to determine true effectiveness.

questions.question: Which theory explains behavior change as a process through stages like precontemplation and maintenance?
questions.explanation: The Transtheoretical Model (Stages of Change) describes progression through stages before sustained behavior change.

questions.question: Which of the following is a key component of effective health education?
questions.explanation: Tailoring educational materials to cultural context improves understanding and receptiveness.

questions.question: What role do peer educators play in health promotion?

options.text: They provide relatable and credible information

questions.explanation: Peer educators can effectively influence behaviors by sharing experiences and serving as trusted sources.

questions.question: Which intervention is best suited for reducing tobacco use in a population?

options.text: Tax increases, advertising bans, and cessation support

questions.explanation: Combining policy (taxes), regulation (advertising bans), and support (cessation programs) produces the greatest impact.

questions.question: What is the significance of the Ottawa Charter in health promotion?

options.text: It focuses solely on medical treatment
It identifies key action areas for health promotion globally
It ignores social aspects of health

questions.explanation: The Ottawa Charter outlines five priority areas including building healthy public policy and strengthening community action.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes a “health literacy” approach?

options.text: Ensuring individuals can access, understand, and use health information
Assuming all populations have the same understanding

questions.explanation: Health literacy empowers people to make informed decisions by improving their ability to comprehend and use health information.

questions.question: Which group is most likely to benefit from targeted health promotion interventions?
questions.explanation: Targeted interventions address disparities and reach groups with greater health risks or less access to services.

questions.question: Which strategy best addresses obesity at the community level?

options.text: Increasing access to healthy foods and physical activity spaces

questions.explanation: Environmental changes support sustainable healthy behaviors more effectively than individual efforts alone.

questions.question: What is the key focus of “empowerment” in health promotion?

options.text: Enabling people to take control over their health decisions

questions.explanation: Empowerment involves increasing individual and community capacity to make choices and transform those choices into desired actions.

questions.question: Which setting is commonly used for health promotion activities?
questions.explanation: Schools, workplaces, and community centers offer access to groups in natural settings for effective health promotion.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of secondary prevention?
questions.explanation: Secondary prevention focuses on early detection and prompt treatment to reduce severity.

questions.question: What is a major barrier to effective health promotion in low-income communities?

options.text: Limited access to resources and information

questions.explanation: Low-income communities often lack access to necessary resources, limiting their ability to engage in health-promoting behaviors.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the ecological model of health?

options.text: Considers multiple levels including individual, interpersonal, community, and policy

questions.explanation: The ecological model recognizes that health is influenced by factors at many levels, from personal to societal.

questions.question: What is a key feature of a successful health promotion campaign?

options.text: Clear, consistent messaging across multiple channels

questions.explanation: Consistency and clarity improve comprehension and retention, essential for behavior change.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a principle of health promotion?
questions.explanation: Health promotion focuses on preventing illness and enhancing well-being, rather than diagnosing diseases.

questions.question: Which health promotion intervention targets individual knowledge and skills?
questions.explanation: Health education aims to increase knowledge and skills for health decision-making at the individual level.

questions.question: Which is the most appropriate evaluation method for long-term health promotion impact?

options.text: Longitudinal studies tracking behavior and health outcomes
Counting the number of flyers distributed

questions.explanation: Longitudinal studies provide insights into sustained behavior changes and health improvements over time.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of tertiary prevention?
questions.explanation: Tertiary prevention aims to reduce disability and improve quality of life after disease has occurred.

questions.question: How does cultural competence improve health promotion?

options.text: By tailoring interventions to cultural norms and values
By focusing only on medical facts

questions.explanation: Cultural competence enhances relevance and acceptability of health messages, improving outcomes.

questions.question: Which health promotion activity would be most effective in a school setting?

options.text: Providing healthy meals and nutrition education

questions.explanation: Combining healthy meals with education addresses both behavior and environment to improve student health.

questions.question: What is the role of policy in health promotion?

options.text: To create environments that support healthy choices

questions.explanation: Policies like tobacco bans and food labeling facilitate healthier choices on a broad scale.

questions.question: What is “motivational interviewing” used for in health promotion?

options.text: Enhancing intrinsic motivation for behavior change

questions.explanation: Motivational interviewing is a counseling method that helps individuals resolve ambivalence and commit to change.

questions.question: Which method best increases community participation in health promotion?
questions.explanation: Involving leaders and stakeholders fosters ownership and sustainability of interventions.

questions.question: Which of the following is a health promotion tool aimed at raising awareness?
questions.explanation: Mass media effectively spreads health messages to large audiences, increasing awareness.

questions.question: What does “capacity building” refer to in health promotion?

options.text: Increasing individual and community abilities to manage health

questions.explanation: Capacity building empowers people and communities to identify and address their health needs.

questions.question: Which is the best example of an environmental health promotion strategy?
questions.explanation: Environmental strategies reduce exposure to hazards and improve overall community health.

questions.question: Which of the following best defines "preventive health behavior"?

options.text: Actions taken to detect and treat illness
Actions taken to avoid disease before it occurs

questions.explanation: Preventive behaviors like vaccination and exercise reduce risk of disease occurrence.

questions.question: What is a limitation of health education if used alone?

options.text: It always leads to behavior change
It may increase knowledge but not change behavior
It is the only needed strategy

questions.explanation: Knowledge alone may not lead to action without supportive environments and motivation.

questions.question: Which of the following is a characteristic of a health-promoting school?
questions.explanation: Health-promoting schools combine education, environment, and services to support student health.

questions.question: Which approach is key to reducing health disparities?
questions.explanation: Tailoring interventions addresses specific needs and barriers in disadvantaged groups.

questions.question: What is the most important factor in sustaining health promotion programs?
questions.explanation: Programs with community ownership are more likely to continue and be effective long-term.

questions.question: Which of the following is a common health promotion outcome indicator?
questions.explanation: Measuring behavior changes such as smoking rates reflects health promotion impact.

questions.question: What is an example of an interpersonal level intervention in health promotion?
questions.explanation: Interpersonal interventions focus on relationships and social support influencing health behaviors.

questions.question: What is the first step in planning a health promotion program?
questions.explanation: Understanding the health needs and priorities guides program design and focus.

questions.question: Which strategy helps overcome health literacy barriers?

options.text: Providing information in simple, clear formats
Assuming all individuals understand medical terms

questions.explanation: Clear, jargon-free communication improves comprehension among diverse populations.

questions.question: Which of the following best illustrates a policy-level health promotion activity?

options.text: Implementing a sugar tax to reduce consumption

questions.explanation: Policy changes, like taxation, affect population-level behavior by modifying the environment.

questions.question: Which principle is critical when developing health promotion messages?

options.text: Tailor messages to the audience’s values and beliefs

questions.explanation: Tailored messages are more persuasive and effective in motivating behavior change.

questions.question: What does “sustainability” mean in the context of health promotion programs?

options.text: Maintaining benefits and activities over time

questions.explanation: Sustainable programs continue to deliver health benefits beyond initial implementation phases.

questions.question: Which is an example of a population-based health promotion intervention?

options.text: Legislation banning indoor smoking in public places

questions.explanation: Population-based interventions target entire communities to prevent disease and promote health.

questions.question: What is the role of a health promoter?

options.text: Facilitating health education and community mobilization

questions.explanation: Health promoters educate, advocate, and mobilize communities to adopt healthier behaviors.

questions.question: Which is a barrier to health promotion in rural areas?
questions.explanation: Rural areas often face transportation difficulties and lack of healthcare infrastructure.

questions.question: How can technology support health promotion?

options.text: By delivering tailored health messages and tracking progress
By limiting access to health information

questions.explanation: Technology like mobile apps and social media can personalize communication and monitor behavior change.

questions.question: What is the focus of “health in all policies” approach?

options.text: Limiting health considerations to healthcare sector
Integrating health considerations into policymaking across all sectors

questions.explanation: The "health in all policies" approach acknowledges that health is influenced by policies across all sectors and aims to integrate health considerations into policymaking broadly.
